reason: Although Restaurant A has a significantly higher objective quality rating (90 vs 60) and is a Michelin-level establishment, its menu is focused on rich, high-end dishes such as Wagyu Beef, Foie Gras, and Lobster Thermidor, which do not align with my preference for Caribbean cuisine or my dairy-free dietary needs. Additionally, the average price per meal at Restaurant A (~$85) is quite high and may not represent good value given its moderate total rating of 3.8 stars from 10 reviews, suggesting mixed experiences despite the premium cost. On the other hand, Restaurant B, while lower rated (60) and a local diner, offers affordable meals averaging $15, which fits comfortably within my middle-class budget of $8K-11.9K. Although its menu is standard diner fare and does not specifically cater to Caribbean cuisine or dairy-free options, the healthier aspect can be better managed here by customizing simpler dishes. Furthermore, as an ambitious individual, I appreciate practicality and value; the quality difference does not justify the large price gap, especially since Restaurant A's menu does not match my food preferences or health needs. Therefore, Restaurant B is the more suitable choice given the balance of cost, dietary accommodation, and reasonable quality.

Although Restaurant B is much cheaper and has slightly lower ratings, its menu and style do not fit my preferences or dietary requirements. reason: While Restaurant A offers a significantly higher quality rating (90/100) and a refined, Michelin-level dining experience, its menu is heavily focused on rich, high-fat, and gluten-containing items such as Wagyu beef, foie gras, lobster thermidor, and caviar blini. This conflicts with my gluten intolerance and low-fat dietary needs. Additionally, although there is a Chocolate Soufflé dessert, the overall menu does not emphasize sweets, and the high price point (average $85 per item) is steep relative to my middle-class budget of $8K-$11.9K, especially when considering the relatively modest 3.8-star average rating from combined reviews. On the other hand, Restaurant B, a local diner with a lower quality rating (60/100), offers affordable pricing (average $15.1) that fits comfortably within my budget. It includes sweet options like milkshakes and apple pie, which align well with my preference for chocolate and sweets, and the menu items are likely more accommodating for gluten intolerance and low-fat requirements, given the simpler fare. Despite the lower overall quality, the friendly service, reasonable quality for the price, and better alignment with my dietary restrictions and sweet preferences make Restaurant B the more suitable and discerning choice for me.
